title: The many ways LGBTQ people will be disenfranchised by voter ID
text:
The effects of these reforms are incredibly wide-ranging. They will affect everyone in the country who wishes to exercise their right to vote (Picture: Tolga Akmen/WPA Pool/Getty Images)

In the Queen’s Speech today, the government has announced plans to require voters to produce photographic ID at the ballot box before being able to vote at all upcoming local and general elections.

The effects of these reforms are incredibly wide-ranging. They will affect everyone in the country who wishes to exercise their right to vote. The proposals are already proving controversial, but what is going under-discussed is the potentially chilling effect this will have on the rights of the millions of lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans people living in the UK.

Studies in the US have shown that restrictive identification requirements there have been particularly disadvantageous to certain voter groups who are less likely to possess government-approved ID for a variety of socioeconomic and accessibility reasons. These groups are traditionally marginalised groups, including LGBT people.

Advertisement

Advertisement

A major part of this is down to the cost. A new driving licence costs £34 if the application is submitted online and £43 if the application is submitted by post, and a new passport costs £75.50 if the application is made online and £85 if the application is submitted by post. This may not seem like much to some, but to others it is more than they have.

So, why does this impact LGBT people in particular? Because LGBT people are statistically less likely to be in full-time employment, and much more likely to face barriers in accessing employment or have to leave a job due to discrimination. Lesbian women and trans women, even when in employment, earn less on average than women in general.

There’s already a heavy financial cost that comes with being transgender, and these reforms will only further add to this burden if a trans person wants to exercise their basic democratic right to vote

Having no fixed address presents another major roadblock to getting approved identification – it’s pretty self-evident that it’s much harder to get a form of ID if you have nowhere to send it to. Homelessness also disproportionately affects LGBT people, with Albert Kennedy Trust figures showing that 24 per cent of homeless young people (aged 16 to 25) are lesbian, gay, bisexual or trans.

All of these problems are compounded and amplified for the trans and non-binary community. A trans or non-binary person’s photo or gender marker on their ID may not reflect their gender expression or identity, and so even if they do have an ID to present, they could face challenges from polling staff. This would likely be distressing and uncomfortable, and may force someone to out themselves as trans or non-binary against their will.

Advertisement

Advertisement

An unintended consequence of this could be that some trans or non-binary people are turned away from voting stations. Anticipating this kind of negative reaction, many trans and non-binary people will be discouraged from going to vote at all.

It shouldn’t be forgotten that trans people already face barriers to registering to vote, with some trans people’s National Insurance numbers being protected and classified by HMRC as ‘sensitive information’. This prevents the voter from registering online. Instead, they have to present themselves with a number of identification documents to their local council in order to register.

There’s already a heavy financial cost that comes with being transgender, and these reforms will only further add to this burden if a trans person wants to exercise their basic democratic right to vote. There are a number of costs incurred to trans people who want to obtain approved ID that reflects their gender. It costs £17 to change your photo on your driving licence. A new passport with a change of gender costs £75, and requires a letter from a GP or medical professional, which costs £25.

This, alongside the increased workplace discrimination and lower levels of employment in the trans community, creates further barriers for trans people in obtaining an approved ID that won’t result in them being turned away at the polls.

Advertisement

There’s still some way to go, but most people would agree that there has been progress for LGBT communities over the past few decades: equal marriage, increased visibility, and the Equality Act have been just a few milestones. None of this could have been accomplished if we hadn’t spoken up and had our voices heard – particularly at the ballot box.

Our vote is more than just putting a cross on a piece of paper, it is a fundamental democratic right. These reforms will likely render thousands of lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans people disenfranchised, and represent a major step backwards for the progress of our communities.
